hint: Standard markup language for documents designed to be displayed in a web browser
Style sheet language used for describing the presentation of a document written in HTML
A document structured with HTML that can be displayed in a web browser
A collection of related web pages linked together under a common domain name
Computer that stores web site files and serves them to users upon request
Application used to access and view websites (e.g., Chrome, Firefox)
Human-readable address of a website (e.g., google.com)
Address of a specific resource on the Web (Uniform Resource Locator)
Protocol used for transmitting web pages over the Internet
Secure version of the protocol used for transmitting web pages
System that translates domain names into IP addresses
Unique numerical label assigned to each device connected to a computer network
Device or software that requests services or resources from a server
Computer or system that provides resources, data, services, or programs to other computers
Message sent by a client to a server asking for a resource
Message sent by a server to a client containing the requested resource
HTTP method used to request data from a specified resource
HTTP method used to send data to a server to create/update a resource

HTML code that defines a specific element (e.g.,

,

)
Individual component of an HTML document, consisting of a start tag, content, and end tag
Provides additional information about an HTML element (e.g., src, href)
Specific setting assigned to an attribute (e.g., 'red' for color)
HTML elements that clearly describe their meaning to both the browser and the developer
HTML elements (h1-h6) used to define titles and subtitles

HTML element (

) used to define a block of text
HTML list (<ul>) where items are marked with bullets
HTML list (<ol>) where items are marked with numbers
HTML element (<li>) used to define an item in a list
HTML element () used to embed a picture
Link from a hypertext file or document to another location or file
HTML tag (<a>) used to define a hyperlink
HTML element (<form>) used to collect user input
HTML element (<input>) used to create interactive controls for web-based forms
HTML element (<label>) used to define a label for an <input> element
HTML element (<button>) used to create a clickable button
Block-level container (<div>) used to group other HTML elements
Inline container (<span>) used to mark up a part of a text, or a part of a document
Semantic element (<header>) representing introductory content or a set of navigational links
Semantic element (<footer>) representing a footer for a document or section
Semantic element (<main>) specifying the main content of a document
Semantic element (<nav>) defining a set of navigation links
Semantic element (<article>) representing a self-contained composition
Semantic element (<section>) defining a section in a document
Semantic element (<figure>) for self-contained content, like illustrations or diagrams
Element (<figcaption>) defining a caption for a <figure> element
HTML element (<meta>) providing metadata about the HTML document
HTML element (<title>) defining the title of the document shown in the browser's title bar or tab
HTML element (<link>) used to link external resources like CSS files
HTML element (<script>) used to embed or reference executable code
The first element in an HTML document specifying the language
HTML element (<strong>) defining text with strong importance

HTML tags that do not require a closing tag (e.g.,
, )
Elements that do not start on a new line and only take up as much width as necessary
Path to a file relative to the current file's location
Complete path to a file, including the protocol and domain
Tool used to check if HTML or CSS code follows the standards
World Wide Web Consortium, the main international standards organization for the World Wide Web
Tool for identifying and reporting on patterns found in JavaScript code
Process of running a program that analyzes code for potential errors
Legal right that grants the creator of an original work exclusive rights for its use and distribution
Creative materials that are not protected by intellectual property laws
License that allows creators to grant permission for others to use their work
Small segment of data sent over a network
One portion of the path between source and destination in a network
Local Area Network, a network that connects computers within a limited area
Transmission Control Protocol, a standard that defines how to establish and maintain a network conversation
User Datagram Protocol, a communication protocol used for time-sensitive transmissions
Set of rules governing the exchange or transmission of data between devices
Organization that manages the reservation of internet domain names
Last segment of a domain name (e.g., .com, .org)
Number returned by a server to indicate the result of a request (e.g., 200, 404)
HTTP status code indicating the requested resource could not be found
HTTP status code indicating the request has succeeded
CSS pattern used to select the element(s) you want to style
CSS property and value pair (e.g., color: red;)
Aspect of an element you want to change in CSS (e.g., color, font-size)
Weight given to a CSS rule to determine which style is applied
Mechanism where certain CSS properties are passed from parent to child elements
CSS property used to set the text color
CSS property used to set the background color of an element
CSS property used to specify the font for an element
CSS property used to specify the size of the font
CSS property used to specify the thickness of characters
CSS property used to set the border around an element
CSS property used to create space around elements, outside of any defined borders
CSS property used to create space around an element's content, inside of any defined borders
CSS property that specifies the display behavior (the type of rendering box) of an element
Color model based on Red, Green, and Blue
CSS concept describing the rectangular boxes generated for elements (content, padding, border, margin)
Keyword added to a selector that specifies a special state of the selected element(s)
Pseudo-class (:hover) activated when the user moves the mouse over an element
Pseudo-class (:active) activated when an element is being activated (e.g., clicked)
Pseudo-class (:visited) used to select visited links
HTML attribute and CSS selector (.) used to define a group of elements
HTML attribute and CSS selector (#) used to identify a unique element
Web-based DevOps lifecycle tool that provides a Git-repository manager
Storage location for software packages or code
Operation which saves your changes to the local repository
Operation which sends your committed changes to a remote repository
Copy of a repository that allows you to freely experiment with changes without affecting the original project
Browser tool that allows you to view and edit the HTML and CSS of a web page
Text description of an image, used for accessibility and when the image cannot be displayed
Instruction that associates a particular HTML document with a document type definition. At the very beginning of an HTML document
Character encoding used in the document (e.g., UTF-8)
CSS rule (@import) used to import style rules from other style sheets
Software (usually a web browser) that acts on behalf of a user
Process of making a website or application available for use
Service that allows individuals and organizations to make their website accessible via the World Wide Web
Interface for typing commands to the computer's operating system
A value passed in a query string (key=value)
CSS layout module (display: flex) for laying out items in one dimension
CSS layout module (display: grid) for laying out items in two dimensions
Web design approach that makes web pages render well on a variety of devices and window or screen sizes
CSS technique (@media) used to apply styles based on the device's general type or specific parameters
Practice of making websites usable by as many people as possible, including those with disabilities
Section of a website intended to aid users in moving through the site
Arrangement of visual elements on a web page
Early sample, model, or release of a product built to test a concept or process
Error, flaw, failure or fault in a computer program or system
Process of finding and resolving bugs within computer programs
Browser tool for logging information and running JavaScript
Browser dev tool for monitoring network requests
Suffix at the end of a filename (e.g., .html, .css)
Another name for a folder in a file system
The top-level directory of a file system or website
An element that contains other elements
An element that is contained within another element
Elements that share the same parent
A parent, grandparent, etc., of an element
A child, grandchild, etc., of an element
Empty space at the beginning of a line of code to show structure
CSS selector (*) that matches any element
CSS selector that matches multiple elements separated by commas
CSS selector (space) that matches all elements that are descendants of a specified element
CSS selector (>) that matches all elements that are direct children of a specified element
CSS property that sets the transparency level of an element
Having an opacity of 0, allowing background to show through
Name of the directory in which your Flask constant files (images, data, etc...) are stored
Name of the main Python file that runs your Flask application
A lightweight WSGI web application framework in Python
A URL pattern that is mapped to a specific function in a Flask application
An HTML file that contains placeholders for dynamic content in a Flask application
Templating engine for Python, used by Flask to render HTML templates
Flask function used to render an HTML template with dynamic content
Command line option to run a Flask application in debug mode
Decorator in Flask used to define a route for a specific URL
CSS rule used to apply styles based on device characteristics like screen size
Scalable Vector Graphics, an XML-based format for vector images
Small icon associated with a website, displayed in the browser tab
Code returned by a server to indicate the result of an HTTP request
JavaScript Object Notation, a lightweight data interchange format that is easy for humans to read and write
